Les presento los informes y sus correspondientes presentaciones que elabor√© durante el 2022-2023 sobre el Paleoclima del Cuaternario tard√≠o en Chile Central y del Antropoceno
column2: desarrollados en el marco de los cursos GL71C-1 Procesos Geodin√°micos en Ambiente de Subducci√≥n

column4: y del curso GL5005-1 Geocronolog√≠a. El primero fue calificado con nota 6.8
column5: mientras que el segundo con nota 6.5. Ambos informes tambi√©n est√°n disponibles en ResearchGate y en LinkedIn.

column1: El primer informe analiza que durante gran parte del Pleistoceno y Holoceno
column2: la zona central de Chile ha experimentado prolongados per√≠odos de aridez
column3: interrumpidos por fases clim√°ticas m√°s h√∫medas. En tiempos hist√≥ricos recientes
column4: se han manifestado condiciones extremas que han derivado en eventos intercalados de sequ√≠as y de inundaciones.

column1: El segundo informe explora que desde 1854 ya se hablaba en la Geolog√≠a sobre los efectos de la industrializaci√≥n en el medioambiente y su registro geol√≥gico en las rocas
column2: siendo denominadas en ese entonces como ""rocas antropozoicas"" las que hab√≠an sido alteradas por actividades humanas

Desde entonces han existido diversas propuestas de como denominar al tiempo geol√≥gico en que la humanidad ha dejado su registro en la faz del planeta. Destacan las siguientes denominaciones en orden temporal: ""Antropozoico"" (1854)
column4: ""Psicozoico"" (1883)
column9: ""Antropostroma"" (1984)

column1: ABSTRACT ¬øQu√© patrones emergen cuando millones de personas recuerdan

column6: abordaremos la polarizaci√≥n pol√≠tica mediante Dynamap
column7: un modelo algor√≠tmico basado en redes neuronales entrenado con comparaciones reales de propuestas pol√≠ticas
column8: capaz de mapear las posiciones ideol√≥gicas latentes de audiencias masivas. Exploraremos tambi√©n c√≥mo la carga moral de mensajes en redes sociales puede parad√≥jicamente limitar su alcance
column9: generando patrones no lineales de propagaci√≥n. Finalmente
column10: estudiaremos la cooperaci√≥n y exclusi√≥n en entornos escolares utilizando redes de interacci√≥n social y experimentos basados en teor√≠a de juegos. Presentaremos la plataforma Capybara

column1: From Software Heritage to Code Commons A vision for transparent and responsible AI in code-based model training""

column2: Inria)
3er. Piso Edificio Norte)

column1: There is a strong interplay between software development and machine learning: AI models are providing new tools to develop software
column2: while the inclusion of large publicly available codebases in training datasets helps improve large language models¬í reasoning abilities
column3: well beyond coding tasks. In the specific domain of source code the issue of transparency of the training dataset assumes a special weight in the broader debate around open versus closed models. Software Heritage
column4: launched by Inria and in partnership with UNESCO
column5: has been building the largest archive of publicly available source code for nearly a decade
column6: and provides today the Software Hash Identifier for the over 50 billion software artifacts it collected from over 300 million projects
column8: guaranteeing integrity and enabling traceability of all its contents. Because of the core values that inform its approach to open access and code preservation
column9: it is naturally concerned by these challenges.

column1: In this talk we will start from the principled stance on the use of the Software Heritage archive for training models
column2: report on the lessons learned from the collaboration with the BigCode project that created StarCoder2
column3: and then focus on the challenges
column4: ethical considerations
column5: and technical limitations that arise in the current approaches to use open codebases in AI
column6: in particular when it comes to transparency
column8: and resource efficiency. These limitations underscore the need for a Code Commons: a dedicated initiative to expand Software Heritage into a central resource for transparency
column9: quality
column11: and sustainability in machine learning on code. By promoting transparency and responsible stewardship
column12: Software Heritage aims to help researchers
column14: and organizations navigate the challenges of AI in code-based applications. This talk invites all stakeholders to collaborate on this ambitious vision.

column1: Bio: An alumnus of the Scuola Normale Superiore di Pisa
column2: with a PhD in Computer Science from the University of Pisa
column3: Roberto Di Cosmo was associate professor for almost a decade at Ecole Normale Sup√©rieure in Paris. In 1999
column4: he became a Computer Science full professor at University Paris Diderot
column5: where he was head of doctoral studies for Computer Science from 2004 to 2009. President of the board of trustees and scientific advisory board of the IMDEA Software institute and chair of the Software chapter of the National Committee for Open Science in France
column6: he is currently on leave at Inria. His research activity spans theoretical computing
column9: the semantics of programming languages
column14: the new scientific problems posed by the general adoption of Free Software
column15: with a particular focus on static analysis of large software collections. He has published over 20 international journals articles and 50 international conference articles.

column2: he has created and coordinated the european research project Mancoosi
column3: that had a budget of 4.4Me and brought together 10 partners to improve the quality of package-based open source software systems. Following the evolution of our society under the impact of IT with great interest
column4: he is a long term Free Software advocate
column5: contributing to its adoption since 1998 with the best-seller Hijacking the world
column7: articles and software. He created in October 2007 the Free Software thematic group of Systematic
column8: that helped fund over 50 Open Source research and development collaborative projects for a consolidated budget of over 200Me. From 2010 to 2018
column9: he was director of IRILL
column10: a research structure dedicated to Free and Open Source Software quality. He created in 2015
column12: an initiative to build the universal archive of all the source code publicly available
